DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Medical Management Timing Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the free-text field to define the timing of administration of medical intervention for a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Relating to the study or practice of medicine._The act of conducting, controlling or supervising something._The chronological relationship between temporal events.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Medical; relating to the study or practice of medicine.:The act of conducting, controlling or supervising something.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Relating to the study or practice of medicine.
The act of conducting, controlling or supervising something.

Property.preferredDefinition: The chronological relationship between temporal events.

Concepts.definition: The chronological relationship between temporal events.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the free-text field related to treatment or therapy.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Text; the words of something written.
